title: Going to Italy...
content:
Hi there!

I’m going to spend a few days in Rome, Florence, and  
Milan in January... Do any of you have any  
recommendations of manuscript, typography, and/or  
printing museums that I should check out? I’m  
particularly interested in incunabula and illuminated  
manuscripts, but I’d love to visit some contemporary  
print shops as well.

Thanks so much!  
Grendl.

p.s. Restaurant recommendations also welcome... and  
apologies for the cross-posting.

 [‹ My Favorite Frame of Helvetica (the film)](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/typophile.com/node/40067 "Go to previous forum topic") [Font problem on Leopard - please help me............! somebody, anybody? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/typophile.com/node/40005 "Go to next forum topic")
author: grendl

comments.content:
There is a lot to see in Rome at the National Museum of Rome, Baths of Diocletian, which contains the Epigraphical Department. Not all this came from there but a lot of it did.

I saw this. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/ebensorkin/sets/72157594336113040/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/ebensorkin/sets/72157594336113040/ "http://www.flickr.com/photos/ebensorkin/sets/72157594336113040/")

I would love to see what you find if you can photograph it.

[http://www.bncf.firenze.sbn.it/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/www.bncf.firenze.sbn.it/)  
 [http://www.ambrosiana.it](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/www.ambrosiana.it/)  
 [http://www.braidense.it/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/www.braidense.it/)

I think you must have an authorization.

I suggest the Museo Bodoniano in Parma (120 km from Milan and on the road form Rome to Milan):  
 [http://www.mb-museobodoniano.it/museo.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/www.mb-museobodoniano.it/museo.htm "http://www.mb-museobodoniano.it/museo.htm")  
I am sure you know Giambattista Bodoni, anyway here is the wikipedia entry about him:  
 [http://www.mb-museobodoniano.it/museo.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/www.mb-museobodoniano.it/museo.htm "http://www.mb-museobodoniano.it/museo.htm")

Last but not least, Parma is famous for food (Parmigiano Reggiano and Prosciutto (ham) di Parma above all) and there are a lot of nice places where to eat.  
My suggestion for lunch is “Sorelle Picchi” ( [http://www.mytravelguide.com/restaurants/profile-79501805-Italy\_Parma\_So...](http://web.archive.org/web/20071218234037/http:/www.mytravelguide.com/restaurants/profile-79501805-Italy_Parma_Sorelle_Picchi.html "http://www.mytravelguide.com/restaurants/profile-79501805-Italy\_Parma\_Sorelle\_Picchi.html")) a nice and peculiar place, since the restaurant is in the backroom of a “salumeria” shop.

e-mail me in private if you need more infos about my town.

ciao  
andrea

I know January is cold, but that’s no reason to not eat gelato on the streets. ;-) I was a poor college student when I went, so I didn’t eat at any restaurants. However, there is a nice cafe in Scandicci (a suburb of Florence) called Bar Mario (or is it Cafe Mario?). It’s just a coffee bar, really, but it’s good.

I went in 1999, and that was before I learned much about typography or took any design classes at all. There’s a lot of great art to be found, especially in Florence: The Uffizi, Palazzo Pitti, L’Accademia...
